channel.title: FBI may GPS you!
channel.description:
[url='https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101016/ap_on_re_us/us_gps_tracking_warrants']Oil change reignites debate over GPS trackers[/url] [quote] SAN FRANCISCO – Yasir Afifi, a 20-year-old computer salesman and community college student, took his car in for an oil change earlier this month and his mechanic spotted an odd wire hanging from the undercarriage. The wire was attached to a strange magnetic device that puzzled Afifi and the mechanic. They freed it from the car and posted images of it online, asking for help in identifying it. Two days later, FBI agents arrived at Afifi's Santa Clara apartment and demanded the return of their property — a global positioning system tracking device now at the center of a raging legal debate over privacy rights. One federal judge wrote that the widespread use of the device was straight out of George Orwell's novel, "1984". "By holding that this kind of surveillance doesn't impair an individual's reasonable expectation of privacy, the panel hands the government the power to track the movements of every one of us, every day of our lives," wrote Alex Kozinski, the chief judge of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in a blistering dissent in which a three-judge panel from his court ruled that search warrants weren't necessary for GPS tracking. But other federal and state courts have come to the opposite conclusion. Law enforcement advocates for the devices say GPS can eliminate time-consuming stakeouts and old-fashioned "tails" with unmarked police cars. The technology had a starring role in the HBO cops-and-robbers series "The Wire" and police use it to track every type of suspect — from terrorist to thieves stealing copper from air conditioners. That investigators don't need a warrant to use GPS tracking devices in California troubles privacy advocates, technophiles, criminal defense attorneys and others..... [/quote] me... I would have said "What property? I dont have any property. I threw it out cuz I couldn't figure out what it was."
And then I would have sold it on ebay. :stuck_out_tongue:

would people care if they were the Federal Bureau of Masturbation? No, because people would get used to imposing characters in dark suits masturbating them all the time.

item.title: FBI may GPS you!
item.dc:creator: Orpheon
item.description:
Just from the fact that everyone knows they exist, they are now rendered effectively useless. In fact, most certainly worse than useless.

Also I love how racist this was. Great work guys! While you were following the Arab, a white guy robbed a bank! I guess they’ll just never learn…

Read full topic

item.title: FBI may GPS you!
item.dc:creator: JeffMOD
item.description:
There’s an idea;
EVERYONE!!! DRIVE YOUR CARS INTO THE POTOMAC!!!
In all seriousness, though, this is terrible, and something I’d expect from an Orwellian gov’t, not one that claims to love freedom. What next, they’ll try to censor the internet?
Oh wait…

Read full topic

item.title: FBI may GPS you!
item.dc:creator: BahamutBBob
item.description:
If I found one of those trackers on my car, I’d either open it up and look inside, or toss it into the Potomac.

But I don’t have a car, or a metal plate anywhere in my body, so they’ll have to resort to tracking my cell phone or keep a visual of whatever I’m doing.

Read full topic
